Posts.Title: anyone have a cold just before surgery? windingshores AndreaJ50

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2015 04:02AM Bounce wrote: I had a cough before my lumpectomy in 2013. My regular doctor said it was from worry about being diagnosed with cancer and that it would pass as soon as I had surgery. I really thought the surgeon would cancel but she didn't seem at all worried even though I was coughing a lot and completely hoarse. The day after the lumpectomy I was still coughing. I went to an ENT and she had a look at my sinuses and prescribed antibiotics. 2 weeks later my cough was gone. And I changed my regular doctor for someone who has a bit more sense (I hope). I remember that being sick did not help my anxiety. I worried more about the cough interfering with surgery than I did about the actual surgery. Sending you good wishes for a speedy recovery from your cold and from surgery. Hugs.
Posts.Title: anyone have a cold just before surgery? windingshores AndreaJ50

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2015 11:57AM Bounce wrote: JJMAMA As a Mom who breastfed I can understand your feelings. While you want to do everything 100% perfectly for your baby all the time - this is not always possible - and now is one of those times. Your baby may not like the formula for 3 days - but he will cope with it much better if you are calm. Given that this is a really tough time for you - try to be accepting of the things that you cannot change - and don't feel guilty that you should have done something different - I never kept frozen breast milk just in case. Also - your baby will be OK. This is not something that will stress him out forever or cause a major problem. Give him a snuggle and some kisses with the formula and all will be well. I don't mean to sound flippant - I perfectly understand your point of view - your stress and your sorrow - I just want to let you know that in 20 years time you will look back at this and remember every detail but your son wont remember it at all. Hugs
Posts.Title: I cried today.... JJMAMA Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2015 12:39PM Bounce wrote: Great news. Hope the original pain disappears. Hugs.
Posts.Title: I cried today.... JJMAMA Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2016 06:07AM Bounce wrote: A few months after I finished rads I felt my breast was still swollen and heavier than pre surgery/pre radiation. MO, RO, breast surgeon and my doctor said it would take much longer for my breast to feel better while not being able to give me a reason for it still hurting. They seemed to think I might feel discomfort for years and were quite happy to tell me so. I found a lymphedema specialist (extra qualified physiotherapist) and after 4 sessions I felt like a new person physically and also psychologically. I highly recommend trying a few sessions unless there is an underlying medical reason not to. Also ask your RO about taking some NSAIDS. I remember taking some for about 2 weeks and that helped a bit before the lymphedema specialist. I must add that I did not have thickening or orange peel - just a swollen, heavy bruised feeling. Best wishes

Posts.Title: When NOT to do MLD? JO-5 JO-5

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2014 08:57PM Bounce wrote: I can't help feeling angry at my RO for: Giving me the impression that if radiation did cause a secondary cancer it would be years and years away,  That it would be easily treated and  For not educating me about what to look out for and  For not recommending any ongoing treatment when I complained of pain and swelling in my breast months after radiation finished. I am grateful to you ladies for educating me. I now understand that I should do as much as I can to prevent lymphedema in my breast - not just for my present comfort but for my future health. Its shocking how ignorant the medical profession is when it comes to lymphedema. Thank you ladies for all your input.  This thread may actually save someone's life.
Posts.Title: When NOT to do MLD? JO-5 JO-5

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2014 06:04AM Bounce wrote: JO-5 - If the annual mammogram aggravates the spot would your doctor and insurance be prepared to do an MRI instead? There might be medical grounds for not doing the mammogram? I have refused to do a mammogram - my cancer did not show on the mammo and I will not risk squashing my tender boob! When the doctor saw I was very serious about not doing a mammogram ever again she said she would request an MRI when its time for my annual checkup. Maybe its an option for you?

Posts.Title: Has anyone had an MRI miss their cancer? oceangirl654 lulu2533

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2013 12:36PM Bounce wrote: Please ask if you have dense breast tissue. If you do INSIST on an ultrasound. You need to find the reason for this pain and mammograms do not show everything especially if you have dense breast tissue. Don't stop asking questions and doing tests until you have an answer. If you have pain your body is trying to tell you something. Listen. My cancer was discovered by ultrasound. It didn't hurt and couldn't be felt (not by me, BS, MO or mammogram technician or biopsy doctor - would anyone else like a feel? ) Look after yourself. You have 3 young children and if there is a problem the quicker you catch it the easier it will be to deal with.

Posts.Title: Can one breast be lumpier than the other? sayheysam sayheysam

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2016 05:06AM Bounce wrote: Hello there sayheysam I had hoped someone with more experience with fibroadenomas would have answered you. Thanks for your kind wishes - so far so good. I would suggest that you do a lot of reading on-line about fibroadenomas - from various sources - medical and possibly alternative medicine - and then find a breast surgeon (or gyno) who is familiar with them and can answer your questions about how to proceed in the future. Two factors that you might want to research are Vitamin D and Iodine. While I am not a great believer in Alternative Medicine I do believe that Vitamin D and Iodine play a big role in breast health. I have no idea how they relate to fibroadenomas - like I said I have no experience with that. My breasts were rather lumpy in my twenties and thirties. I got cancer in my late forties and in my case I am sure it is genetic - given my family history. Do please update us after your ultrasound. Best wishes Bounce
Posts.Title: Can one breast be lumpier than the other? sayheysam sayheysam

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2014 11:36AM Bounce wrote: Hi Jessica13 - sorry to hear you are having trouble. It is very difficult knowing what to do sometimes. If you are having frequent meltdowns try to get to speak to a therapist with cancer experience.  Obviously they are not going to solve your problems for you in a second but it really helps to understand what is going on in your own head and heart. I have been at the meltdown stage.  It was not fun. If you can get yourself a bit calmer speak with the RO as soon as possible to clarify and tell him you feel you were lied to and are concerned about the lymphedema. It is an issue for many women after radiation and is not something that should be overlooked by the RO. Do you feel that the lymphedema is worse since starting rads? The RO should be available to you to discuss any problems you are having. Don't worry about asking to see him or what he thinks - do what is right for you. Sometimes I found the radiation nurse more helpful.Sometimes I wished I had never spoken to her. I can't see your diagnosis and in any case I have no medical training so can't offer advise about stopping or continuing rads. I just think your concerns are valid.  Meditating before speaking to my RO helps me be more calm.  I decide on what questions I must have answers to and try not to leave until they have been answered.  Not easy for me by any means. Deep calming breathes. My brief therapy helped me a lot with how I deal with doctors. Gentle hugs

Posts.Title: I've been treating BC naturally Blubelle Momine

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2014 03:58PM Bounce wrote: The MRI will not miss it.  Whatever part of your body needing the MRI will be positioned to be in the machine. Some people get claustrophobic -some don't mind at all. The MRI does not give any radiation like other xrays and scans - so that is good. It does make a fair bit of noise which can be unpleasant.  You should ask them to play music if possible - that gave me something to distract me and also a way of telling time. My husband has had MRI's.  He meditates and has been known to fall asleep. I wanted to add that dense breasts don't show a lot on mammograms.  My cancer was seen only by ultrasound (and MRI) - even knowing where it was no-one could feel it. If you are calm - mammogram and your ultrasound were ok -  then its fine to wait until the 17th - otherwise try to see the BS sooner.
Posts.Title: Palpable Lump, Negative Mammogram and U/S MyLittleTrout sarahjane7374

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2013 01:57AM Bounce wrote: Exercise and diet. Mostly I have been using an exercise bike but I believe walking is a better exercise. Am also planning on using a "theraband" thingy and a ball for using different muscle groups - all do-able at home without spending a lot of money. If anyone has links already to theraband exercises on the internet I would appreciate it if you could share them. Diet - no sugar, no white flour, no bread at all - so far have lasted 3 months but show signs of snapping! Am eating lots of quinoa and black lentils and salad and fruit. With exercise - I started slow - could only do 3 minutes on the bike! Now I am up to half an hour. Also take Vitamin D as I am D deficient.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2017 05:50AM Bounce wrote: I must say that I found my biopsy quite rough. I had had fine needle aspirations before and was not expecting the punch punch punch feeling. Although I did not have pain it was not pleasant. Some women have a really bad time of it. I fully understand your feeling that you were put through a useless procedure - but as others have explained - had cancer been found - the treatment options may have been different. It is also hard to know if you can rely on what people are doing or not if you have a bad experience along the way. It kind of messes things up. If possible find a breast surgeon you can trust - someone who is happy to answer questions - and be guided by them on all future issues.
Posts.Title: ***Unnecessary Biopsy after AD/Radial Scar Diagnosis?!! Concerned2018 Monique72

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2014 02:33PM Bounce wrote: Sorry to confuse matters but I would go for the MRI rather than the biopsy - especially if its a core biopsy - it wasn't a good experience for me and left a bruise the size of my breast and a scar.  Also it only gives info about one area. Sure you have to wait for the MRI and the results - but you will know more about the general state of both breasts from an MRI. On the down side if the MRI does show something you will still have to do the biopsy.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2015 12:48PM Bounce wrote: Emu oil might be beneficial during radiation but it doesn't do the Emu's much good to be turned into oil! There is scientific research showing calendula oil is more helpful than most other products for preventing skin problems during radiation. I was happy with using Calendular oil. I still occasionally use it.

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2017 09:06AM - edited Dec 18, 2017 09:08AM by Bounce If a biopsy confirms cancer - then the lumpectomy will include a sentinal node biopsy. Starting with a lumpectomy to diagnose cancer would mean additional surgery if cancer was discovered.  I am sorry that you are in the situation you find yourself in. It must be beyond frustrating. Perhaps a second opinion could shed some more light on the issues.
